Chapter 8, Part 3: Distinguishing Cognition, having explained the TathÄgata's unique merits, now we shall discuss the common merits.
Verse:
There are also other Buddha-dharmas, shared with other noble ones and ordinary beings,
Namely, the merits of non-contention, aspiration-prayer cognition, unobstructed understanding, and so forth.
Discussion:

The World-Honored One also has immeasurable merits shared with other noble ones and ordinary beings, namely, non-contention, aspiration-prayer cognition, unobstructed understanding, spiritual powers, meditative absorptions, formless attainments, samÄdhis, immeasurable liberations, spheres of mastery, and spheres of totality, and so forth.
According to their respective applications, the first three are only shared with other noble ones, while spiritual powers, meditative absorptions, and so forth are also shared with ordinary beings.

Although all the merits in the Buddha's body are pure in aspects, superior, and sovereign, they are said to be shared based on the similarity of their categories, differing from the merits of Å›rÄvakas and others.
Moreover, among the three qualities of the other saints, what is non-conflict?
Verse:
Non-conflict is conventional knowledge, unshakable in the fourth meditation,
In the three continents, conditioned by future arising, desire realm afflictions.
The treatise says:

There are arhats who remember many past lives, experiencing various bodies and giving rise to afflictions for themselves and others. Due to this, they continue to experience unpleasant results. They then think like this:
If a body with afflictions gives rise to afflictions when conditioned by it, it still attracts painful results, let alone a body free from afflictions with superior qualities.
Having thought this, they give rise to such a characteristic of knowledge. By this means, they cause other sentient beings not to give rise to greed, anger, etc. when conditioned by their bodies.
This knowledge is only conventional knowledge by nature, because it conditions future afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation in others, and is not a pure knowledge that turns in this aspect.
If the substance of non-conflict is included in knowledge, how is it said to cultivate the samÄdhi of non-conflict, etc.?
This is not contradictory, because a single thought unit has many merits, and one is mentioned.
Just as a single mountain has many things, and one is mentioned to indicate the name of the mountain.

Reason should be free from dispute, which is included in knowledge. Protecting the continuity of others and the arising of future afflictions, skillful means are foremost, and then affairs are accomplished.

However, all disputes are generally of three kinds, because of the distinctions of aggregates, speech, and afflictions. The dispute of aggregates refers to death, the dispute of speech refers to fighting, and the dispute of afflictions refers to the one hundred and eight afflictions.
Because of this, worldly knowledge can stop and eliminate the dispute of afflictions, and therefore it is called free from dispute.
This knowledge only relies on the fourth meditative absorption, because it opposes the cause of suffering.

Because the path of ease in the fourth meditative absorption is the most excellent, the fruit of non-retrogression can arise, not others. Others are not yet able to prevent the arising of their own afflictions, let alone be able to stop the afflictions of others' bodies.
This is only based on the human bodies of the three continents, not on the northern continent or others, because its nature is fierce and sharp.
It arises in response to the occurrence of actual delusions in the desire realm, in order to prevent the arising of delusions in others on the basis of oneself.
As for the non-actual delusions, it is impossible to block and prevent them, because they arise internally and are able to generally take as their objects whatever is appropriate.
The discussion of non-contentiousness is finished.
What about the cognition of vows?
The verse states:
The cognition of vows can universally take as its object. The rest is explained as in the case of non-contentiousness.
The treatise states:
It is called the cognition of vows because it is able to understand in accordance with the vow, drawing forth wondrous cognition by taking the vow as its forerunner.
The intrinsic nature, stage, type, and body of this cognition are the same as those of non-contentiousness, but its object is different, because it takes all dharmas as its object.
How can the cognition of vows know the future?
Because it is able to infer it by carefully observing the past and present.
It is just as one observes that crops are sometimes abundant and sometimes meager, and infers that the fields are sometimes fertile and sometimes poor.
If this is so, why is it called the cognition of vows?
because learners and ordinary beings can also know it.
If this were not so, then what is to be known would not be definitely so.

It is said by transmission that when the great disciples make predictions about future events, they are sometimes wrong, but this is not because their knowledge of vows is mistaken. This is because they make predictions by means of other worldly knowledge.
Or, it is not the case that their predictions are wrong, but they only see the beginning and do not see the end, just as rain falls from the sky but does not reach the ground.
For example, Rahula was originally a boy, but later he changed into a girl.

Or, for example, the ghosts of RÄjagá¹›ha were victorious in the first battle, but later they were defeated by the ghosts of VaiÅ›ÄlÄ«. This is because the ghosts fight first when humans want to fight.

Or, it is true that knowledge of vows directly sees the future, but when one is preparing to make a prediction, one first generates inferential knowledge and observes the past and present in order to infer the future. Only after this can one truly see the future by generating knowledge of vows.

On the basis of this, one can also know the formless realm. That is, one first contemplates the causes and outflowing results of the formless realm, and inferential knowledge is produced. This induces the true knowledge of vows.

Or, one contemplates the mind of death and birth in the realms of desire and form, and by inference one knows the place of rebirth. This induces the knowledge of vows and one is then able to truly know.

Or, it is also not a mistake to say that inferential knowledge knows. Because the object of the knowledge of realization and inferential knowledge must be the same. If one does not know by inference, how can one realize?
Then it follows that the knowledge of vows should not be said to be able to universally take the three realms and three times as objects.

When a perfected being of non-obstructed liberation wishes to correctly understand the objects of the three realms, he first makes a vow, â€œMay I know them.â€ Later, he enters the fourth meditative absorption of the limit of the world as a preliminary practice. Immediately after this, in accordance with the power of the vow, he induces the arising of correct knowledge and fully understands the objects of the vow.
The term â€œlimit of the worldâ€ will be explained later.
How does the power of this knowledge of vows differ from the knowledge of past abodes?

The knowledge of the object of one's vow and the knowledge of others' minds know both the specific and general characteristics, while the knowledge of past abodes only knows the general characteristics and not the specific ones.
Within the knowledge of the general characteristics, there are also distinctions. The knowledge of the object of one's vow is clear, while the knowledge of past abodes is not.
The distinction between the knowledge of others' minds in the present object should be considered in the same way.
The knowledge of the object of one's vow has been explained.
What are the unobstructed understandings?
The verse states:
There are four unobstructed understandings, namely the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, meanings, expressions, and eloquence.
They are by nature the non-retrogressive cognition of names, meanings, expressions, and paths.
The unobstructed understanding of dharmas and expressions is only worldly cognition, and they are based on the first two stages.
The unobstructed understanding of meanings is based on all stages, and the unobstructed understanding of eloquence is based on nine stages.
One who obtains one necessarily possesses all four, and the rest are explained like the unobstructed understanding of non-conflict.
The treatise states:

The unobstructed understandings are generally said to be four: the unobstructed understanding of dharmas, the unobstructed understanding of meanings, the unobstructed understanding of expressions, and the unobstructed understanding of eloquence.
These four are generally said to be, in their order, the unretrogressive knowledges that have as their objects names, meanings, words, and the path.
That is, unretrogressive knowledge that has as its object the names, phrases, and syllables that express dharmas is established as the first.
The path to the expressed meaning is called a name, which is to say, it reveals the meaning of the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
The discrimination of the expressed meaning is called a phrase, which is to say, it discriminates the meaning of the specific characteristics of dharmas.
It is not necessary to have the sound of the meaning in order to generate understanding, which is said to be a syllable, which is to say, it is the basis for the generation of understanding.
It is reasonable to have understanding without the sound of the meaning, but this understanding should not be without an object, and this object is said to be a syllable.
A syllable is not able to directly indicate meaning but only serves as the basis for the expression of meaning by names and phrases.
These three are able to hold all the expressed meanings and generate understanding, and for that reason they are called dharmas.
The three natures are called bodies because they are the substance of the bodies and are different names for them.

The three are extremely mixed with the meaning of sounds, and it is difficult to know their distinct characteristics when they arise as objects of consciousness. Therefore, the word body is used to show that they have separate substances.
If there is no regressing cognition that takes all dharmas as its object, the supreme truth is established as the second truth.

Although the specific and common characteristics of all dharmas are called bodies, etc., they are also included in the truth, but they are not the supreme truth because there are many conceptual thoughts.

That is to say, there is the truth and there is that which is not the truth, there is the meaningful and there is the meaningless, there is that which evolves based on the provisional and there is that which evolves based on the real. Understanding this without interval or at a later time, all that is measured is called the supreme truth. In order to show the unobstructed understanding of the truth,
the object that is its support is neither speech nor names. Therefore, its object is said to be the supreme truth.

That is to say, it only takes as its object the names that arise based on speech, and the meaning that is manifested by the names. It does not take as its object the general mental activity that is called the truth.
If one has no knowledge of the languages of various regions, one establishes a third one.
One is then able to understand worldly languages and sacred words, and the various differences in the various regions.
If one has no knowledge of speech that accords with reason and is unobstructed, and of the two paths of concentration and wisdom, one establishes a fourth one.
One is then able to proclaim the words and meanings correctly and without obstruction, which is called eloquence.
And all the merits that one has already attained, which manifest spontaneously without effort and have sovereign power, are also called eloquence.
This is able to give rise to eloquence, and is established with the name of eloquence.

Knowledge of eloquence and its causes is called the unobstructed understanding of eloquence.ğŸ”½The correct proclamation mentioned above, which skillfully responds to the capacities of beings and does not contradict the supreme truth, is called speech that accords with reason.
The unobstructed words mentioned above, which do not depend on place, time, sentient beings, etc., and are sovereign in analysis, are called unobstructed.
The merits already acquired that are manifested spontaneously without the need for further effort are called mastery.
The two paths of samÄdhi and prajÃ±Ä, which are able to understand each other, are called the first two unobstructed understandings.

That is to say, understanding that this name belongs to such and such meaning, and understanding that this meaning has such and such a name, is called the understanding of the correspondence between the able and the to-be-understood. Understanding the words and phrases of temporal activities, etc., is called the third unobstructed understanding.
Understanding the cause of the path of delight in speech and mastery is called the fourth unobstructed understanding.

Moreover, the six kinds of objects of knowledge such as form are called meaning. The distinctions such as conditioned and unconditioned, form and non-form, etc., of these good, etc., are called phenomena. The words that express these two are called language.
The three kinds of knowledge are the first three unobstructed understandings. The knowledge that is unobstructed with regard to the three kinds is called the fourth unobstructed understanding.
Moreover, understanding the two truths of the conventional and the ultimate is called the first two unobstructed understandings.
This is the perfection of the practitioner's own benefit.
Skillfully expounding these two truths is called the third unimpeded understanding.
Skillfully answering questions and penetrating difficulties is called the fourth unimpeded understanding.
This is the perfection of benefiting others by practitioners.
Some say that stupidity, doubt, and distraction are the causes of obstruction in eloquence.

By being liberated from these three, one attains abiding in present happiness, and by this, the practice of benefiting others is accomplished. This wisdom is called the unimpeded understanding of eloquence.
If one attains such concentration, one can expound in accordance with correct principles, with unimpeded speech, and attain the merits of mastery in the present.
Moreover, in the unimpeded explanation of the ultimate meaning of names, etc., one attains skill in each. The four unimpeded understandings are established in sequence.
The first three skills are called the causes, because the objects are different and have distinctions. The fourth is the result, which is able to explain without obstruction.

Moreover, the four kinds of unhinderedness are established because the work of benefiting others is accomplished by means of four parts, namely, skill in the letter, understanding of the meaning, mastery of the sounds and tones, and freedom in samÄdhi and wisdom.
This is the general explanation of the substance of the four unhinderednesses, and it also shows the differences in the objects of the four.
The scriptures briefly mention the number and names of the four, and the Abhidharma extensively reveals their characteristics.
Also, the scriptures list meaning first and then the Dharma, while the Abhidharma lists the Dharma first and then meaning.

This is because when the two knowledges arise, either the meaning is based on the name or the name is based on the meaning. Therefore, the scriptures and the treatises make distinctions in their explanations.

That is to say, the listener first distinguishes the name. Having correctly known the name, he next seeks its meaning. Having correctly known the meaning, he wishes to explain it to others, and next he must seek the knowledge of unhindered explanation. The order is based on this. Therefore, the name comes first.
However, among these four, the knowledge of meaning is the most excellent, and the others are its companions. Therefore, meaning comes first.

That is, if one has correct understanding of the meaning, next one should seek the name that expresses it. Having already known the name, if one wishes to explain it to others, next one should seek the knowledge of skillful explanation. Therefore, these four are in this order.
If the four unimpedednesses take speech as their object when explaining, how are they different from the third unimpededness of elocution?

The third unimpededness is the ability to understand and explain words, such as saying that because it has the characteristic of obstruction, it is called form, etc. This is unimpeded explanation that accords with reason.
Some say that elocution expresses the intrinsic nature of dharmas, while eloquence is able to reveal the distinctions among dharmas.

Some say that with regard to dharmas, directly speaking in words is elocution, while being able to analyze without obstruction is eloquence. The difference between the two is in the third and fourth unimpedednesses.

Among the four, the unimpedednesses of dharmas and elocution take worldly cognition as their nature, not pure cognition, because they take as their objects the collections of names, etc., and worldly expressions.

The unobstructed understanding of dharmas is based on five stages, namely, the desire realm and the four fundamental meditations, because above there are no names, etc., and because they do not separately take the names, etc., of lower stages as objects.

The unobstructed understanding of expression is based only on two stages, namely, the desire realm and the first fundamental meditation, because above, in the other stages, there is no applied thought or sustained thought, and because there is no self-expression in those stages.
This reason is unreasonable.
Why is this?
The unobstructed understanding of dharmas is not the knowledge that expresses speech, because it is not the case that the unobstructed understanding of dharmas does not exist in samÄdhi.
For this reason, one should not say that it does not exist in the upper stages because there is no applied thought or sustained thought.
There is no fault in this, because the meaning of the reason is different.
What is the meaning of the reason?

It means that in the mind and speech of the desire realm and the first meditation, the two dharmas of applied thought and sustained thought are able to express speech, and their characteristics are not tranquil, and their natures are coarse and agitated.
Because they do not exist above, they are tranquil and subtle.

The unobstructed understanding of elocution takes external words as its object, and it is not tranquil, being categorized as coarse and agitated. Therefore this understanding does not exist in the upper stages.
Since there is also applied thought and sustained thought in the first trance state, therefore this understanding also exists within samÄdhi.
Consequently, it is definitely established that it is supported by only two stages.

The unobstructed understanding of meaning is of the nature of the sixteen kinds of knowledge. If all dharmas are called meaning, then it is of the nature of the ten kinds of knowledge. If only nirvÄá¹‡a is called meaning, then it is of the nature of six kinds of knowledge, i.e., conventional, knowledge of the dharma, subsequent knowledge, knowledge of extinction, knowledge of nonproduction, and knowledge of the nonarising of that which has not yet arisen.
The unobstructed understanding of elocution is of the nature of nine kinds of knowledge, i.e., excluding the knowledge of extinction, because it has as its object the path that is spoken.
These two kinds of unobstructed understanding are produced by supporting all stages, i.e., they are supported by the realm of desire up to the peak of existence.
It is not erroneous to say that the unobstructed understanding of elocution is supported by all stages, because it is admitted that it is produced by supporting any one of the paths that are spoken.
However, among them, that which has as its object only the speaker is supported by only two stages, the same as the third.
Some say that the extinction and nonproduction knowledges are not included in the unobstructed analytical knowledges, because the unobstructed analytical knowledges are by nature views.
They say that the second is either four or eight, and the fourth is only seven. This should be understood in accordance with the above.

It should be understood that, as in the case of the four noble families, if one obtains one of the four unobstructed analytical knowledges, one necessarily obtains all four. One cannot be said to obtain them if one does not obtain all four. One may or may not manifest them as one wishes.
Other masters say:

There is no obtaining of only a part of the four. There is no reason to require that one obtain all four once one obtains one.ğŸ”½Some say that the four unobstructed analytical knowledges are born from the prior practices of calculation, the Buddha s word, language, and logic. If one does not acquire skill in these four areas, one is certainly unable to generate the four unobstructed analytical knowledges.

In reality, the generation of all four unobstructed analytical knowledges is only a matter of the prior practice of the Buddha s word. One must have previously acquired skill in names, etc., before one can cultivate the four unobstructed analytical knowledges.

The term asraya means support. The name of the four unimpeded wisdoms has many meanings. It is called unimpeded wisdom because one is unimpeded in understanding various objects.ğŸ”½Or it is called unimpeded wisdom because one is unimpeded in decisively understanding various objects.
Or it is called unimpeded wisdom because one is unimpeded in correctly speaking about various objects.
Other masters say:
The wisdom that is non-erroneous in the presence of objects is called unimpeded wisdom.
These four are based on the same stage, nature, and object as non-contention.

The above has already explained the nature and body of support, as explained in non-contention. That is to say, the nature of non-contention is based on the bodies of humans in the three continents. As for the non-contention wisdom and so forth that have been explained, the verse says:
The six are attained at the limit, the limit is the sixth, the subsequent concentration,
Universally following to the ultimate, the Buddha and others attain through practice.
The treatise says:
The six kinds of non-contention, vow wisdom, and four unimpeded wisdoms are all attained at the limit of concentration, because they are drawn out by the power of the limit of concentration.

The substance of the extreme trance is of six kinds. The first six are excluded, and the rest are of five parts, and in addition to this there is a superior trance obtained by added effort, called extreme trance, and thus it is made up of six kinds.

Although the unimpeded power of expression is based on this, its substance is not included in the trances. The name extreme is based only on the fourth trance, because it is followed by all stages, and because it increases to the ultimate, it is called extreme.
For this reason, it should not be common to the other stages.
How is this called followed by all stages?

When one is correctly cultivating and studying this trance, one enters in order from the first trance up to the peak of existence. One then enters in reverse order from the peak of existence up to the first trance. One enters in order from the first trance and in succession up to the fourth trance. This is called followed by all stages.
How is this called increasing to the ultimate?

That is, one cultivates the fourth trance exclusively, from the lower to the middle, and from the middle to the higher. These three grades are each divided into three. The highest of the highest grade is called reaching the ultimate. This trance is called the extreme limit.
In this case, the three vehicles are not without distinctions, but each is called ultimate in its own way.
The word extreme here shows the meaning of not going beyond. The others do not go beyond this, so it is called the extreme.
The word limit is used to show the meaning of category and the ultimate, like the words four limits and actual limit.

These two words show that this trance is the most excellent category, the ultimate among concentrations, because it produces the most excellent qualities and is the most excellent among pleasant practices.
The above-mentioned knowledges such as non-disputation, except for the Buddha, are only attained through added effort and not through detachment, because not all are attained.
Only the Buddha attains them both through detachment and through added effort.

The merits of the Buddhas are all attained suddenly at the time of the knowledge of termination, because of the abandonment of passion. Later, they are able to manifest them as they wish, and they are not due to added effort, because the World Honored Buddhas turn freely with regard to all dharmas.
The first three are common to other saints.
We should now discuss the common qualities.
The verse says:
The six supernormal powers are: the supernormal power of the spiritual penetrations, the heavenly eye, the heavenly ear, the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds,
the knowledge of past lives, and the supernormal power of the extinction of contamination. They are included in the path of liberation and wisdom.
Four are conventional knowledge, and knowledge of othersâ€™ minds is five. The supernormal power of the extinction of contamination is like the power.
Five are based on the four meditations. The objects are the stages below.
The Å›rÄvaka, the rhinoceros, and the Buddha have two, three thousand, and innumerable.
They are not due to added effort. They are attained by separation from passion through cultivation.
Three are of the body, one is of the other three, and one is of the Dharma. The last four are of the Dharma and the other three.
The heavenly eye and ear are indeterminate. The other four supernormal powers are only good.

There are six kinds of penetration: 1) penetration of the knowledge of the marvelous function of spiritual powers, 2) penetration of the knowledge of the divine eye, 3) penetration of the knowledge of the divine ear, 4) penetration of the knowledge of the minds of others, 5) penetration of the knowledge of the recollection of past lives, and 6) penetration of the knowledge of the extinction of contamination.
Although the sixth is possessed only by saints, the first five are also obtained by ordinary beings. Speaking in general terms, they are also common to ordinary beings.
These six kinds of penetration are categorized as paths of liberation, and their nature is that of discernment, just as is the case with the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
The term â€œpath of liberationâ€ indicates the meaning of being free from obstacles, because it is also found in the path of added effort.

In this state of penetration and discernment, there is no uninterrupted path, because this state definitely prevents the knowledge of the minds of others, and because one must not allow the arhat to be said to abandon the knowledge of the extinction of contamination when he abandons the uninterrupted path.
With the exception of the knowledge of the minds of others and the knowledge of the extinction of contamination, the remaining four are categorized as conventional knowledge.
The penetration of the knowledge of the minds of others is categorized as five knowledges, namely, knowledge of the law, subsequent, path, conventional, and knowledge of othersâ€™ minds.
The power of the extinction of contamination is like the power of knowledge, that is, it is either six or ten knowledges.
This already shows that the knowledge of the extinction of contamination is based on all stages and has all as objects.

The first five supernormal powers are based on the four meditations, not on the formless realm, nor on the intermediate meditation, because they do not have the concentration that is the support of the five supernormal powers.

The support of the five supernormal powers is the concentration that subsumes the members, but the power of the extinction of contamination is not so, because it can have all stages as objects and the extinction of contamination, and it does not depend on observing form as its added effort.
The objects of the first three supernormal powers are not formless, because these three supernormal powers only have form as their objects.
The cultivation of the supernormal power of knowing othersâ€™ minds has form as its door.

The cultivation of the supernormal power of knowing past lives gradually recollects the differences in states and only then succeeds. In its added effort, it must observe form, and therefore it is not able to be based on the formless realm.
If this is so, the intermediate and five preliminary stages of the formless realm may also have form as an object, and there should be five supernormal powers.

This is not so, because of the previously mentioned reason, i.e., that the samÄdhi that includes the members is the support of the five supernormal powers. If it does not include the members, samÄdhi is weak, and also because of the deficiency of either calm abiding or insight.
If this is so, why does the power of knowledge of the extinction of contamination have slow and fast realization in the stages of pleasure and suffering?
Because it is able to extinguish contamination.
The first five are superior qualities cultivated separately, and one can only generate them in superior stages.
When one cultivates the first three supernormal powers of spiritual penetrations, etc., one imagines lightness, light, and sound as added effort. Once accomplished, one is free to do as one wishes.

Those who wish to cultivate the supernormal knowledge of the minds of others first carefully observe the two characteristics of their own body and mind, the changes that occur before and after, and the succession of these changes. Then they carefully observe the characteristics of the body and mind of others. Through this added effort, they gradually succeed. Once accomplished, without observing their own mind and form, they are able to truly know the minds of others.

Those who wish to cultivate the supernormal knowledge of the recollection of past lives first carefully observe the mind that has just ceased, and then gradually reverse their observation to the state of this life, further and further back, to the mind of the linking of rebirth, and finally they are able to recollect and know the one thought of the intermediate state prior to this life, which is called their own past lives.
When the preparatory practice is completed, the practice for recollecting others is also like this.

When this supernormal knowledge first arises, it only knows in sequence. When it becomes habitual, one is also able to recollect by skipping over. All that is recollected is that which has been experienced. One recollects the Pure Abodes because one has heard about them in the past.

Those who die in the formless realm and are reborn here first give rise to this supernormal knowledge based on the life-stream of another. The rest also give rise to it based on their own life-stream.

The objects of these five supernormal knowledges are only in the lower stages.ğŸ”½For example, in the case of the supernormal knowledge of the divine eye, one is able to see the forms of the lower stages wherever one is born.
If one is born in the higher stages, one is not able to see the forms of the lower stages.
The same is so for the other four supernormal knowledges, as is appropriate. Therefore, one is not able to take the formless realm as an object.

As for the scope of the five supernormal knowledges, the sages of the various schools differ in their opinions as to the extent of the world that can be reached by the functioning of these supernormal knowledges.

That is, the great ARHAT, the pratyekabuddha, and the great enlightened one, if they do not concentrate their attention, can, respectively, cause their bodies to appear and transform in one, two, and innumerable worlds.

If they concentrate their attention, they can, respectively, cause their bodies to appear and transform in two thousand, three thousand, and innumerable worlds.ğŸ”½As for these five supernormal knowledges, if one has not acquired them from beginningless time, one acquires them through practice.
If one has cultivated them and they are not powerful, and if they are of the same kind as those acquired through the path of cultivation, one acquires them through the elimination of passion.
If one causes them to appear, it is always through practice.
The Buddha acquires them through the elimination of passion and can cause them to appear at will without practice.

The five supernormal knowledges of the saints of the three vehicles and of ordinary beings who are reborn are of two kinds, acquired and unacquired. The five supernormal knowledges of other ordinary beings are all acquired.
As for the distinction of the six supernatural powers in terms of the four foundations of mindfulness, there are two different meanings, one based on objects and the other based on substance.
Some say that the first two supernatural powers are the divine eye and ear, and the remaining four are by nature wisdom.
They say that the divine eye and ear are the objects of the foundation of mindfulness of the body, and the remaining four are all the objects of the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas.

However, in reality, the six kinds are all by nature wisdom, because the scriptures say that they are all able to understand objects. Consequently, they are all the objects of the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas.
If we distinguish them in terms of substance, then among the six supernatural powers, the first three are only body, because they only take form as objects.
That is, the supernatural power of the spiritual penetrations takes the four external sense bases as objects, the divine eye takes form as objects, and the divine ear takes sound as objects.

If this is so, then why does the knowledge of death and rebirth know that a class of sentient beings is formed by the evil deeds of body, speech, and mind in the present body, and not by the divine eye?

There is a separate superior knowledge that is an associate of the supernormal powers. It arises in dependence on the holy body and is able to know in this way. It is attracted by the power of the supernormal knowledge of the heavenly eye, and therefore it is combined with the supernormal powers and given the name of the knowledge of death and rebirth.

The supernormal knowledge of the minds of others is included in three applications of mindfulness, namely, the mindfulness of dharmas, the mindfulness of mind, and the mindfulness of dharmas, because it has mind, etc., as its object.
The supernormal knowledge of the recollection of past lives is included in the application of mindfulness to dharmas.

Although a scripture says that one recollects the suffering, happiness, etc., that one has experienced, this is the recollection of the suffering, happiness, etc., of past lives. The various implements that one has experienced are miscellaneous objects.
The supernormal knowledge of the extinction of contamination is either the power or the dharma or the four.
If one distinguishes the six supernormal knowledges according to whether they are good, etc., there is an opinion of other masters.
They say that the six are all good.
But in reality, the supernormal knowledge of the heavenly eye and ear is only indeterminate in nature, while the remaining four supernormal knowledges are all good.
The author of the commentary explains this as follows:
The supernormal knowledge of the heavenly eye and ear is categorized as indeterminate, because it is discernment associated with the eye and ear consciousnesses.
